articles.title: Daily briefing: Damaging the climate could violate international law, court rules
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02369-1A landmark court ruling could open the door for nations most affected by climate change to sue the most polluting countries. Plus, an artificial intelligence model that can predict lost Latin text and a fish-inspired medical device that sticks to slippery surfaces.
articles.content:
A landmark court ruling could open the door for nations most affected by climate change to sue the most polluting countries. Plus, an artificial intelligence model that can predict lost Latin text and a fish-inspired medical device that sticks to slippery surfaces.

Hello Nature readers, would you like to get this Briefing in your inbox free every day? Sign up here.

Fragment of a military diploma from Sardinia. AI model Aeneas can predict text lost from a damaged inscription (grey text) without needing to know the length of the section that is missing.Credit: Yannis Assael et al./Nature

An artificial intelligence model called Aeneas can predict where ancient Latin texts come from, estimate their age and restore any missing parts. Researchers trained Aeneas on snippets of text from three of the world’s largest databases of Latin inscriptions, comprising more than 175,000 entries. The model also supports its output with a list of similar inscriptions from the data set, ranked by how relevant they are to the original inscription. When put to the test on well-known texts, Aeneas’s predictions about their age and location-of-origin were similar to that of historians.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: Nature paper

Solid gold can take the heat

Scientists say they’ve heated solid gold to fourteen times its melting point before it melted. The team used a laser to rapidly heat a 50-nanometre-thick sample to 19,000 kelvin for trillionths of a second before it melted and exploded. Testing such ‘superheating’ of metals is relevant for subjects such as the study of molten planetary interiors. But the result of the experiment has raised eyebrows among physicists. “Do we exceed the melting temperature 10–14 times before melting? I do not think so,” says Artur Tamm, a computational physicist who reviewed the paper.

Nature | 5 min read

Reference: Nature paper

The United States is once again withdrawing from UNESCO, the United Nations science and cultural organization, ending its two-year return to the agency. Researchers say the decision is a setback for global cooperation in science and education, but came as no surprise. The country, a founding member, last withdrew from UNESCO in 2017, during the first term of President Donald Trump, cutting off more than 22% of the agency’s funds. According to UNESCO, the latest withdrawal won’t hit as hard as in 2017 because the US contribution now accounts for 8% of UNESCO’s current annual budget.

Nature | 4 min read

Features & opinion

To make energy, organisms either respire aerobically, using oxygen, or anaerobically, without oxygen. Some species can do both, but for years, researchers didn’t think any organism could do them at the same time. Now, a hardy bacterium that grows in hot springs has thrown a spanner in the works. Scientists found that the species, coined Hydrogenbacter RSW1, could use sulphur to keep its respiration ticking over if there’s no oxygen available — a process that continues even when the bacterium begins to respire aerobically.

Quanta | 8 min read

Researchers have unveiled a new medical device that can stick to soft, moving surfaces, such as the lining of the gastrointestinal tract. The team were inspired by remora, a family of fish that use a similar, sucker-like organ to hitch a ride on larger animals as they swim. The team hopes that such a device can one day be used to deliver medicine to internal organs by sticking to its inner walls, or to monitor disease symptoms such as acid reflux.

Nature | 4 min video

Reference: Nature paper

Image of the week

Stephan N. F. Spiekman et al/Nature

At first glance, you might think that the large protrusion coming from the back of this 247-million-year-old fossil — the newly-discovered Mirasaura grauvogeli — is made of feathers. But, researchers have confirmed, you’d be wrong. Instead, it’s a ‘skin appendage’ — a series of flat, stiff structures that extend vertically from the spine of the reptile. Such structures push the boundaries of what researchers thought reptile skin could achieve, as they’re neither feathers nor covered in scales. “They also must have been awkward to carry around, given that the longest is more than one-third of the length of the entire creature,” writes evolutionary biologist Richard Prum. (Nature News & Views | 6 min read, Nature paywall)

articles.personality_title: Court ruling says harming the climate may break international law
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Climate change is one of the biggest challenges facing the world, with some countries suffering more from its effects than others. Until now, it has been hard for these countries to hold the biggest polluters legally responsible for the damage caused.

**What happened**
A landmark court decision has ruled that harming the climate could violate international law. This means that countries most affected by climate change may now have the legal right to sue those who pollute the most. This ruling opens a new path for environmental justice on a global scale.

**Impact**
This decision offers hope that the world's biggest polluters could be held accountable, encouraging them to reduce emissions and protect the planet. It also empowers vulnerable nations to seek justice and support for the damage they face from climate change.

**What’s next step**
Countries and international groups will likely use this ruling to bring cases against polluting nations. This could lead to stronger global climate actions and better protections for vulnerable communities.

**One-sentence takeaway**
A new court ruling could help the world fight climate change by holding polluters legally responsible under international law.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un tribunal estime que nuire au climat peut enfreindre le droit international
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Le changement climatique est l’un des plus grands défis mondiaux, certaines nations en souffrant plus que d’autres. Jusqu’à présent, il était difficile pour ces pays de tenir les plus gros pollueurs responsables légalement.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Une décision judiciaire historique a statué que nuire au climat pourrait violer le droit international. Cela signifie que les pays les plus touchés par le changement climatique pourraient désormais poursuivre en justice les plus gros pollueurs. Cette décision ouvre une nouvelle voie pour la justice environnementale mondiale.

**Impact**
Cette décision donne de l’espoir que les plus gros pollueurs soient tenus responsables, les incitant à réduire leurs émissions et à protéger la planète. Elle permet aussi aux nations vulnérables de réclamer justice et soutien face aux dégâts climatiques.

**Prochaine étape**
Les pays et organisations internationales vont probablement utiliser ce jugement pour engager des poursuites contre les nations polluantes. Cela pourrait renforcer les actions climatiques mondiales et mieux protéger les communautés vulnérables.

**En une phrase**
Un nouveau jugement pourrait aider à lutter contre le changement climatique en tenant les pollueurs responsables selon le droit international.
articles.personality_title_es: Un tribunal dictamina que dañar el clima puede violar el derecho internacional
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
El cambio climático es uno de los mayores desafíos del mundo, y algunos países sufren sus efectos más que otros. Hasta ahora, era difícil que estos países responsabilizaran legalmente a los mayores contaminadores.

**Qué pasó**
Una decisión judicial histórica dictaminó que dañar el clima podría violar el derecho internacional. Esto significa que los países más afectados por el cambio climático podrían ahora demandar a los que más contaminan. Esta decisión abre un nuevo camino para la justicia ambiental a nivel global.

**Impacto**
Esta decisión ofrece esperanza de que los grandes contaminadores sean responsables, alentándolos a reducir emisiones y proteger el planeta. También da poder a las naciones vulnerables para buscar justicia y apoyo por los daños causados por el cambio climático.

**Próximo paso**
Es probable que países y grupos internacionales usen esta decisión para presentar casos contra naciones contaminantes. Esto podría fortalecer las acciones globales contra el cambio climático y proteger mejor a las comunidades vulnerables.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Una nueva decisión judicial puede ayudar a combatir el cambio climático responsabilizando legalmente a los contaminadores según el derecho internacional.
